title: CFTC Says Enforcing Risk-Management Rules Is a Priority
summary: In a first, swaps regulator charges bank with violating risk-management regulations put in place after financial crisis. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission for the first time charged a bank with violating risk-management rules adopted after the financial crisis, a signal to the industry to bolster internal controls in their swaps businesses.

title: Justice Department Weighs Collecting DNA From Migrants in Custody
summary: Proposed rule injects new civil-rights issue into debate over U.S. immigration-policy changes. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department is planning to require collection of DNA from immigrants crossing the U.S.-Mexico border and others in immigration detention for use in a national criminal database.

title: At Least Seven Killed in Vintage Bomber Plane Crash in Connecticut
summary: The aircraft was attempting an emergency landing at an airport, a state official said. At least seven people were killed Wednesday when a World War II-era bomber crashed while attempting an emergency landing at a Connecticut airport, a state official said.

title: Tesla Sets Record for Car Deliveries, but Challenges Remain
summary: The electric-car maker said it delivered 97,000 in latest quarter; will need to deliver at least 104,800 more to meet full-year goal. Tesla Inc. delivered a record number of cars in the third quarter, but faces the pressure of topping that number in the next three months to meet its full-year target.

title: House Committees, Trump Brawl Over Ukraine Records Requests
summary: Democrats accuse White House of 'flagrant disregard' as Trump lashes out at 'Do Nothing Democrats'. WASHINGTON-The House committees leading an impeachment inquiry into President Trump said they planned to issue a subpoena to force the White House to turn over records related to a pair of phone calls between Mr. Trump and Ukraine's president on a day when each side took to the microphones to accuse the other, in stark terms, of bad faith.

title: Boeing Prioritized Costs Over Safety, Engineer Alleges
summary: Employee who filed complaint contributed to development of 737 MAX jet. A Boeing Co. engineer involved in the development of the 737 MAX claims the aerospace giant's managers overly prized controlling costs and schedules at the expense of safety, allegations that are currently part of a federal criminal investigation after two fatal crashes of the aircraft.

title: Blackjewel Cleared to Sell Wyoming Coal Mines Ensnared in Bankruptcy
summary: Sale tied to larger deal to pay Blackjewel LLC workers who protested after getting bad paychecks. A federal judge has approved the sale of two Wyoming coal mines that were shut down when their owner Blackjewel LLC filed for bankruptcy, finalizing part of a larger deal to compensate workers including those who staged a weekslong protest when they were suddenly left unpaid.

title: More Deals, at Higher Valuations, for Business-Software Makers
summary: Corporate demand for data-driven insights feeds M&A some worry about a bubble. Large technology companies are buying enterprise-software makers in record numbers, even as prices continue to climb.

title: The Whistleblower Executive
summary: Every call with a foreign leader is now subject to congressional review.. The impeachment process is barely underway and already some constitutional norms are being trampled without a note of media notice or political concern. To wit, can a whistleblower inside the intelligence bureaucracy override a President's right to executive privilege merely with an accusation?

title: The Red Meat Rethink
summary: Go ahead and have that steak, and hold the climate politics.. Where's the Pepto Bismol? The medical-academic complex is experiencing a bad case of indigestion over new research this week in the Annals of Internal Medicine that rescinds the longtime recommendation to eat less red meat. Climate politics is now infecting even nutritional science.

title: The Sanders Health Scare
summary: The betting markets elevate Warren as the likeliest nominee.. When the question of candidate age has bubbled up in the 2020 Democratic presidential race, it's usually taken the form of murmurs about 76-year-old Joe Biden's verbal stumbles and memory lapses. Unlike Mr. Biden, 78-year-old Bernie Sanders has seemed as focused and relentless as ever. But Wednesday's news that Mr. Sanders is suspending campaign events after getting cardiac stents for an arterial blockage raises the age issue anew.

title: 'Big Bad Trusts' Are a Progressive Myth
summary: Today's tech titans, like yesterday's industrial giants, will diminish in time thanks to competition.. The resurgence of progressivism in America has brought growing support for a return to Progressive-era trustbusting. Sen. Elizabeth Warren has a plan to break up tech companies like Google, Amazon and Facebook . Berkeley professor Robert Reich, once the resident progressive of the Clinton administration, opines, "Like the robber barons of the first Gilded Age, those of the second"-the tech giants-"have amassed fortunes because of their monopolies." Even in Amazon's hometown of Seattle, a newspaper headline declares, "Big tech needs to face a Theodore Roosevelt-style trust busting."

title: A Policeman's Death and the Life I Didn't Lead
summary: After 9/11, I had the desire to take on a dangerous job. Brian Mulkeen had the guts to do it as well.. Everyone knows police work is dangerous. summary: The Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps and its proxies control Syrian land near the Golan Heights.. title: 'Saving America's Cities' Review: A Downtown Developer
summary: Urban planner Ed Logue's legacy can be seen in New York's Roosevelt Island and Boston's Government Center. Other projects floundered.. If Logue was forgotten in 1997, he's totally unknown now. So kudos to Harvard professor Lizabeth Cohen for exhuming the cantankerous, ambitious and idealistic Logue in her charming and successful biography-cum-urban affairs history, "Saving America's Cities."

title: Johnson's Last-Ditch Brexit Bid Meets Skepticism in EU
summary: Prime minister submits proposals to solve Brexit riddle that paralyzed Parliament: the Irish border. MANCHESTER, England-British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's new proposals to break the deadlock over Brexit met with some skepticism from European officials Wednesday, setting the stage for weeks of tense political maneuvering before the U.K.'s scheduled exit from the European Union on Oct. 31.

title: Colombia's Peace Agreement Is Succeeding
summary: Colombia has its problems, but readers of your editorial "No Peace in Our Time in Colombia" would be surprised to learn that since the signing of a peace agreement in 2016 between the government and the FARC guerillas Colombia has enjoyed the lowest levels of violence nationally since the mid-1970s.. Colombia has its problems, but readers of your editorial "No Peace in Our Time in Colombia" (Sept. 17) would be surprised to learn that since the signing of a peace agreement in 2016 between the government and the FARC guerillas, Colombia has enjoyed the lowest levels of violence nationally since the mid-1970s and thousands of Colombians are able without fear to visit rural regions of the country that have been off limits for decades. Under the agreement, 13,049 full-time FARC combatants and part-time militia members turned in their weapons and demobilized. About 8% are unaccounted for-lower than usual in negotiated peace settlements-but that doesn't mean they all went back to war. Some, mostly small farmers, returned to their daily lives. Others continued drug trafficking or rejected the peace agreement on ideological grounds.

title: Blackstone to Acquire 65% Controlling Interest in Great Wolf Resorts
summary: Blackstone, Centerbridge Partners to form new $2.9 billion joint venture to own resort company. Water-park owner Great Wolf Resorts Inc. is continuing its wild ride through private-equity ownership.

title: Japan Is Honoring Its Treaty Commitments
summary: Article II-1 of the 1965 agreement between Japan and the ROK stipulates that all problems concerning claims between both countries and nationals were "settled completely and finally.". The Sep. 7 letter "Japan Is Not Keeping Agreement With Korea" from the government of the Republic of Korea (ROK) makes a misleading argument on the issue of former civilian workers from the Korean Peninsula during World War II.

title: What's Causing the Decline Of Our Bird Population?
summary: This is a disaster caused by human behavior. To put the blame on climate change is a stretch.. The decline of the bird population in America simply follows a pattern of many people spraying their yards, predicated on the notion that insects-mosquitoes, flies, etc.-are spreading various types of diseases ("Bird Numbers Dive In North America," U.S. News, Sept. 20). This has led to the decline of bees, butterflies, fireflies and other useful insects upon which birds feed. Not to mention the massive spraying of farmlands. It also has been reported that wind turbines lead to the demise of many birds. This is a disaster caused by human behavior. To put the blame on climate change is a stretch.

title: Problem Is a Lack of Guts, Not the Budget Process
summary: What's wrong here is not the process. It is the lack of courage to match spending and revenue.. Sen. Ron Johnson's solution is to put the budget on autopilot and remove all congressional responsibility for it ("Close the Book on Shutdowns," op-ed, Sept. 23). He's worried about the process when he and his colleagues should be worried about the outcome. It is not the broken process that got us into $22 trillion of debt. It was the conscious voting to spend more than we raise in tax revenue and the conscious voting against raising taxes to pay for it all.

title: Campus Censorship Really Isn't the Senate's Problem
summary: It is not clear why the federal government, through the vehicle of Senate "oversight," should have any role whatsoever in how private institutions manage their affairs in this area.. The assaults on open discussion on college campuses cited by Sen. Chuck Grassley are indeed troubling ("The Senate Takes On Campus Censorship," op-ed, Sept. 26). But it is not clear why the federal government, through the vehicle of Senate "oversight," should have any role in how private institutions manage their affairs in this area any more than in their course offerings or academic standards.

title: Peruvian Vice President Resigns After Congress Fails to Oust Nation's Leader
summary: Move boosts President Martín Vizcarra in his showdown with lawmakers over how to rid the country of its endemic corruption. LIMA-Peru's vice president abruptly resigned a day after the opposition-controlled Congress had tried to install her as interim leader, boosting President Martín Vizcarra in his showdown with lawmakers over how to rid the country of its endemic corruption.

summary: Sale of 150 missiles follows earlier shipment of 210 Javelins. The Trump administration plans to sell more Javelin antitank missiles to Ukraine, U.S. officials said Wednesday, moving forward with a sale that Ukraine's president sought in his July 25 call with President Trump.

MATE RIMAC SELLS lightning in a bottle. Founder of Rimac Automobili, near Zagreb, Croatia, the 31-year-old entrepreneur has emerged as a wunderkind in electric-vehicle hyperpower, contributing battery technology to auto makers including Aston Martin, Renault, Pininfarina , and Koenigsegg. title: Credit Suisse Chief Faces Spy Scandal Aftermath Without Trusted Adviser
summary: Tidjane Thiam leans heavily on a close inner circle to enforce and execute strategy at Switzerland's second-biggest bank. Tidjane Thiam arrived at Credit Suisse Group AG in 2015 and quickly established a tight inner circle of trusted lieutenants as he set about trying to revive the ailing Swiss lender.

title: U.S. Private Sector Added 135,000 Jobs In September
summary: Average per-month private job creation over past three months down from last year's 214,000, ADP says. Private employers in the nonfarm sector added more jobs in September than economists expected, but the pace of job creation remains muted compared with last year.

title: New York Fed Adds About $42.1 Billion to Financial System
summary: Bank uses the repo market to relieve funding pressure in money markets. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $42.05 billion to the financial system Wednesday by using the market for repurchase agreements, or repo, to relieve funding pressure in money markets.

title: Premier League Names David Pemsel as Its New CEO
summary: After a nine-month search and at least two false starts, Pemsel will guide the world's most popular sports league amid the shifting media landscape. After a nine-month search and at least two false starts, the most popular sports league on the planet finally found someone to lead it. The Premier League on Wednesday appointed David Pemsel of the London-based Guardian Media Group as its new CEO, immediately making him one of the most influential executives in sports.

title: The Ball Finally Bounces the Nationals' Way in the Postseason
summary: Washington rallied to score three runs in the bottom of the eighth inning to stun Milwaukee 4-3 in the NL wild-card game. The stench of October failure follows the Washington Nationals like a shadow, the product of a generation of disappointment and missed opportunity that defines the franchise. Four times this decade they made the playoffs. All four times they fell in the first round, often in painful and embarrassing fashion.

title: The Opulent Flower Company That Never Says No
summary: Delphinium ceiling? No problem. British florist McQueens, known for its eye-catching arrangements in London's best five-star hotels, lands in Manhattan. For the past three decades, many of London's five-star hotels-among them Claridge's, the Connaught, the Berkeley, Rosewood, the Mandarin Oriental and Shangri-La-have turned to McQueens Flowers for the floral arrangements that subtly but unmistakably shift the weekly appearance of their lobbies, dining rooms and suites. McQueens's creations have also been regular features at international events like the Vanity Fair Oscar party. This year, McQueens has established its first official design studio outside of the U.K., in Manhattan, and it has already begun working with New York clients, including the Peninsula Hotel, the NoMad Hotel, Moda Operandi, Dom Pérignon and Christie's. An atelier and flower school will open in March.

title: Painter Julie Mehretu's Intellectual Ambitions
summary: A new retrospective in November at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art traces Julie Mehretu's career creating epic, lyrical works that are literally ripped from the headlines. There are few artists who follow the news as closely as the painter Julie Mehretu does, and fewer still who directly mine it for their work. But not all viewers of her immense abstract pieces realize it.

Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: USA Swimming Faces Probe Into Sex-Abuse Claims, Business Practices
summary: Prosecutors look into 'money trail' between the national swimming organization, its insurance firm and affiliated foundation. Federal prosecutors in New York are investigating USA Swimming, including allegations that the organization stifled athlete sexual-abuse claims, concealed its assets and improperly reaped hundreds of thousands of dollars in rebates from its in-house insurance company, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Clemson Might Be Great. Its Conference? Not So Much.
summary: The defending national champions could finish the season having played 10 straight games against unranked opponents. Clemson is the defending national champion of college football and has the sport's longest current winning streak at 20. But a close call last weekend against unranked North Carolina has exposed what may be the Tigers' biggest weakness: their easy schedule for the rest of 2019.

title: Baryshnikov Arts Center Names New President
summary: Resume Subscription. In her nearly three decades as president of the New 42nd Street nonprofit organization, Cora Cahan led the charge to restore historic theaters near Times Square and bring new life to the area.

title: U.S.-China Factory Breakup Is Hard to Do
summary: For the first time in a long time, U.S. factories seem to be doing worse than Chinese ones. Chinese factories are suddenly looking a bit healthier. U.S. manufacturers aren't. While some Beijing-based trade warriors may be gloating and Washington-based ones sulking, investors shouldn't jump to conclusions.

title: Pedro Almodóvar's Personal 'Pain and Glory'
summary: Director Pedro Almodóvar calls his new film 'the most intimate representation of me'. "My life makes its way into every film I make, but this is the most intimate representation of me, an extension of myself," Pedro Almodóvar says of "Pain and Glory," his film opening Oct. 4. In it, Antonio Banderas play a Spanish director who shares Mr. Almodóvar's spiky hair, childhood memories, personal fears and even his back problems. The heroin habit and other dramatic details are solely the character's.

title: Why Your Used Shirts Are Destined for the Dump and Not the Recycling Center
summary: Resume Subscription. Shoppers are buying more clothes and discarding them faster than ever, a trend that is sending an increasing amount of textiles to the dump and propelling the fashion industry to search for new technology to recycle used garments.

title: Margarine Gets a Vegan Butter Rebrand
summary: Plant-based food trend has arrived at a convenient time for one of Europe's riskiest private equity deals. Consumers' growing appetite for plant-based food is well-timed for one of the more precarious private equity deals of recent years.

title: Postmates, DoorDash Want to Deliver Your Groceries, Too
summary: Delivery companies are striking deals beyond restaurants to expand their reach and revenue. Food-delivery companies are adding supermarkets and convenience stores to their order queues.

title: UBS Economist Set to Return After Leave for 'Chinese Pig' Comment
summary: Paul Donovan, put on leave in June, is set to come back to work. The Swiss bank declined to say how its business has fared since the furor.. A top UBS economist whose mention of a "Chinese pig" sparked a furor in the Chinese securities industry is scheduled to return to work Wednesday.

title: Facebook Scrambles to Keep Libra on Track as Partners Waver
summary: Some of Libra's backers decline Facebook's requests to publicly support the project. Cracks are forming in the coalition Facebook Inc. assembled to build a global cryptocurrency-based payments network.

title: CEO of U.K. Grocery Giant Tesco to Step Down
summary: Dave Lewis will be replaced next summer by Ken Murphy, a top executive at Walgreens. LONDON-The head of Tesco PLC, one of the world's largest grocery chains, is stepping down and handing the reins to a top executive at pharmacy giant Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc.

title: Borealis Explores Possible Sale of Fertilizer Unit
summary: Move by Vienna-based company comes as fertilizer prices remain well below their highs of 2011. LONDON-Borealis AG, a closely held global chemicals producer, is looking to find a partner or sell its fertilizer business in a deal that could value the business around $1 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

summary: Launch is the country's ninth since July 25. SEOUL-North Korea fired at least one ballistic missile off the country's east coast, officials in Japan and South Korea said, with the U.S. describing the launch as a provocation.

title: Hong Kong Student Shot by Police Is 'The Bravest Type,' Cousin Says
summary: Tsang Chi-kin, 18, is first hit by live round, in what police say was self-defense. HONG KONG-The high-school student shot in the chest by police during a street battle on Tuesday is a seasoned protester who is "never afraid to speak his mind and would put his words into action," according to a cousin.

title: American Energy-Permian Basin Locks Down Out-of-Court Restructuring
summary: The private-equity-owned oil and gas driller reached a deal to restructure about $2 billion of debt outside of bankruptcy. Private-equity-backed American Energy-Permian Basin LLC rounded up enough support from creditors to restructure about $2 billion in debt without resorting to bankruptcy, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Nike CEO Was Briefed by Banned Coach on Doping Efforts
summary: Anti-doping agency's report on ban of coach Alberto Salazar and Dr. Jeffrey S. Brown details Nike's knowledge of their experiments with performance-enhancing drugs. Nike-backed running coach Alberto Salazar on numerous occasions briefed top Nike Inc. officials, including Chief Executive Mark Parker, on his experiments to manipulate the use of performance-enhancing drugs for track and field athletes, according to emails referenced in reports published by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency on Monday.

title: Johnson & Johnson to Settle Ohio Opioid Lawsuits for $20.4 Million
summary: Settlement comes ahead of trial scheduled for this month; J&J is fourth drugmaker to settle with two Ohio counties suing over opioid epidemic. Johnson & Johnson on Tuesday said it has agreed to a $20.4 million deal to avoid a coming trial accusing the company of helping spark an opioid-addiction crisis in two Ohio counties.

title: State Department Draws Scrutiny in Impeachment Probe
summary: House leaders will question two key witnesses as they clash with Pompeo over access. House leaders set plans to question two key State Department witnesses after Secretary of State Mike Pompeo sought Tuesday to block the effort, in the first clash between congressional Democrats and the Trump administration of the newly minted impeachment inquiry.

title: Hong Kong Protester Shot by Police Amid Widespread Violence
summary: A day of bitter fighting marks the worst and most widespread violent unrest to hit the city in more than half a century. HONG KONG-A police officer shot a young antigovernment protester in the chest during the worst day of violent unrest to hit Hong Kong in half a century, as Beijing celebrated the 70th anniversary of Communist Party rule in mainland China.
